data.title: Improperly serialized keybindings
data.body:
### STR
1. Install [amVim](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=auiworks.amvim) or any extension that contributes a key whose command contains a double quote or ends in a backslash.
2. After restarting, click the "Keyboard Shortcuts" item from Preferences submenu.
3. Find that command name in the "Default Keyboard Shortcuts" editor.
### Results

When serializing the command names, vscode doesn't escape the backslashes or double quotes that appear in the command name.  (Key names get escaped properly.)

![screenshot from 2016-02-12 16 06 12](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17192031/13021894/476aa7ae-d1a3-11e5-8efe-74cbc0612285.png)
Screenshot of generated "Default Keyboard Shortcuts" editor with amVim installed.

data.title: Java import directives shown with package names as keywords
data.body: When editing Java in Visual Studio Code, import directives are shown with the package names in blue as if they were keywords.  They should be shown in black because they are identifiers.

data.title: Java primitive types treated as identifiers, not keywords
data.body: When editing Java in Visual Studio Code, primitive types such as `boolean`, `int`, `long`, etc. are shown in black as identifiers.  They should be shown in blue as keywords.

data.title: Failed to load tslint library
data.body:
When I open a project and then open any TypeScript file I see this alert at the top of editor:

"Failed to load tslint library. Please install tslint in your workspace folder using 'npm install tslint' or 'npm install -g tslint' and then press Retry."

I have tslint installed as npm package in my project, as well as global npm package. However, for some reason, editor can't find it.

My editor version is 0.10.8 and I'm on Mac.

Can't debug mocha unit test with VS Code version 0.10.8
data.body:
Hi, I've used to debug mocha unit tests prior this version. Now I get the following error, when I try to run Debug:
request 'launch': cannot launch program 'g:\Repos\Repo1\project1\node_modules.bin\mocha'; enabling source maps might help

I try to debug .js sources (not .ts), so I don't need source maps. My launch.json file:
{
                "name": "Debug",
                "type": "node",
                "request": "launch",
                "program": "./project1/node_modules/.bin/mocha",
                "stopOnEntry": false,
                "args": ["project1/lib/test/*_/_.js"],
                "cwd": ".",
                "runtimeExecutable": null,
                "runtimeArgs": [
                                "--nolazy"
                ],
                "env": {
                                "NODE_ENV": "development"
                },
                â€œexternalConsole": false,
                "sourceMaps": false,
                "outDir": null
},

data.title: Why are we updating breakpoints in the debug adapter when editing files?
data.body:
In discussions with the react team, we noticed that VS Code is sending setBreakpointRequests to the debug adapter. The problem is that these breakpoints are registered with their new source location with node (or any other backend), but that still the old source is executed (because the back end does not support live update, or because the source needs to be compiled first).

We should not do this automatically (unless the debug adapter tells the front-end to do so).

data.title: Breakpoint locations are updated after code edits even before saving
Distribute VS Code via a signed apt repository
data.body: This would make auto-updating possible on Debian-based OS's.

data.title: Allow disabling parameter hints
data.body:
Hey guys, I love vscode and use it for javascript every day, but the IntelliSense pop-up has caused me a good deal of frustration recently because it always seems to pop up when I'm typing and it prevents me using the up/down arrows until I hit escape. It's probably very useful and I just don't understand how to use it, but I was surprised to learn there is no way to disable it. The user settings make a reference to it but only provide two options and both are disabled by default. Hopefully it's appropriate for me to make a suggestion here to allow users to disable it.

![intellisense popup](http://i.stack.imgur.com/4LLw4.png)

Pass 'locale' to debug protocol Initialize request
data.body: Pass 'locale' to debug protocol Initialize request.

data.title: Folding - Activating extension `vscode.typescript` failed: Path must be a string. Received undefined.
Ligatures are not working correctly for F# syntax
data.body:
I am using [Fira Code](https://github.com/tonsky/FiraCode) and have enabled `editor.fontLigatures`. Using a `sum` list function as an example,

``` fsharp
let inline sum list =
    let rec sumImpl acc = function
        | [] -> acc
        | h :: t -> sumImpl (h + acc) t
    sumImpl LanguagePrimitives.GenericZero list
```

The `[]` and the `::` ligatures are not displayed when **F#** language mode is chosen (The `->` ligature is displayed though). However, they are displayed correctly when **Plain Text** language mode is chosen. Is there something wrong with how the syntax highlighter parses F#'s keyword/literal token?

Maybe it's related to #2872?

data.title: Folding - match in folded region is skipped
data.body:
- Create some text with a folding region that includes `foobar`
- Fold this region
- Start a find for `foobar` 

-> the find box shows the correct number of matches, but when you want to step through them the match in the folded region isn't shown.

The expected behaviour is that the folding region expands to show the match.

data.title: Node debugger variables undefined
data.body:
I was debugging https://github.com/editorconfig/editorconfig-vscode and noticed something odd. 

![screen shot 2016-02-12 at 12 52 38](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1913805/13006233/b988451a-d187-11e5-9f8d-2b1a257452db.png)

As you can see in the left pane, `savedDocument.fileName` is `undefined`. But in reality, it is not because `basename(savedDocument.filename)` returned `.editorconfig`, otherwise I couldn't go inside the if statement.

To be clear, it is a TypeScript project (as it is an extension), so not sure for vanilla JavaScript projects. Seems a quite important bug to be honest.

@bpasero Are you able to pass this to the right person? Thanks :)

data.title: [js] Incorrect colorization after properties called new
data.body:
